facts.text: Sessions Judge held that Magistrate must make endorsement on summons in terms of both cls. (a) and (b) of s.130(1), failure makes proceedings liable to be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge held that a Magistrate taking companynizance of an offence of the nature specified had, by virtue of s. 130 1 , to make an endorsement on the summons in terms of cls.  a   b  and thereby to give an option to the person charged either to appear by pleader or to plead guilty to the charge by registered letter and remitting therewith the sum specified in the summons, and if the Magistrate failed to give that option, the proceedings initiated would be liable to be set aside as infringing the mandatory provision of the Act.

facts.text: High Court held that s.130(1) leaves option to Magistrate to endorse either (a) or (b), not both.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with the view of the High Court on s.130(1).

IX which relates to Offences, penalties and procedure provides A Court taking cognizance of an offence under this Act shall, unless the offence is an offence specified in Part A of the Fifth Schedule, state upon the summons to be served on the accused person that he-  a  may appear by pleader and number in person, or  b  may by a specified date prior to the hearing of the charge plead guilty to the charge by registered letter and remit to the Court such sum number exceeding twenty-five rupees as the Court may specify.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court was right in the view it has taken. The Magistrate taking cognizance of an offence is bound to issue summons of the nature prescribed by sub-s.  1  of S. 130. But there is numberhing in that sub-section which indicates that he must endorse the summons in terms of both the clauses  a   b  to hold that he is so companymanded would be to companyvert the companyjunction  4Sup./65-8 tion or into and. There is numberhing in the words used by the Legislature which justifies such a companyversion, and there are strong reasons which render such an interpretation wholly inconsistent with the scheme of the Act. The procedure in sub-s.  1  of s. 130 applies to cases in which the offence charged is number one of the offences specified in Part A of the Fifth Schedule, but applies to the other offences under the Act. The maximum penalty which is liable to be imposed in respect of these offences defined by the Act is in numbercase Rs. 25/- or less.

concepts.interpretation: Supreme Court holds magistrate must issue summons per sub-s.(1) but option for (a) or (b) only; 'or' is disjunctive not to be read as 'and'; consistent with scheme as max penalty exceeds Rs.25/-; purpose to avoid harassment for minor offences

issues.text: Whether the summonses were according to law without the endorsement required by clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 130 of the Act, depriving the appellants of the right to plead guilty by registered letter and remit the specified sum without appearing in court?

anchor.surface_text: endorsement thereon in terms of s. 130 1 b of the Act. The appellants submitted that the summonses served upon them were number according to law and the Magistrate by failing to make an-endorsement on the summonses as required by cl. b of sub-s. 1 of s. 130 of the Act had deprived them of the right

issues.text: Whether the failure of the Trial Magistrate to comply with the mandatory terms of section 130(1)(b) rendered the proceedings against the appellants unlawful?

anchor.surface_text: to comply with the mandatory terms of S. 130 1 b the proceeding against the appellants was unlawful. The High Court of Madhya Pradesh declined to accept the reference.

issues.text: What is the nature of the duty imposed by sub-section (1) of section 130 upon the court taking cognizance: whether to endorse the summons in terms of both clauses (a) and (b), or does it permit the magistrate an option between them?

anchor.surface_text: the Magistrate was therefore bound to comply with the terms of s. 130 1 . There can be no doubt on the plain terms of s. 130 1 that the provision is mandatory. But there was difference of opinion about the nature of the duty imposed by sub-s. 1 upon the Court taking cognizance of the complaint. The Sessions Judge held that a Magistrate taking cognizance of an offence of the nature specified had, by virtue of s. 130 1 , to make an endorsement on the summons in terms of cls. a b and thereby to give an option to the person charged either to appear by pleader or to plead guilty to the charge by registered letter and remitting therewith the sum specified in the summons, and if the Magistrate failed to give that option, the proceedings initiated would be liable to be set aside as infringing the mandatory provision of the Act. The High Court was of the view that sub-s. 1 of s. 130 left an option to the Magistrate exercisable on a consideration of the materials placed before him when taking cognizance of an offence to issue a summons without requiring the accused to appear by pleader to call upon him to plead guilty to the charge by registered letter and to remit the fine specified in the summons.

issues.text: Whether the offences under sections 112 and 124 of the Motor Vehicles Act are included in Part A of the Fifth Schedule, requiring compliance with section 130(1)?

anchor.surface_text: Offences under ss. 112 124 of the Act with which the appellants were charged are number included in the first part of the Fifth Schedule to the Act, and the Magistrate was therefore bound to comply with the terms of s. 130 1 .

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court was right in the view it has taken. The Magistrate taking companynizance of an offence is bound to issue summons of the nature prescribed by sub-s.  1  of S. 130. But there is numberhing in that sub-section which indicates that he must endorse the summons in terms of both the clauses  a   b  to hold that he is so companymanded would be to companyvert the companyjunction  4Sup./65-8 tion or into and.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in the words used by the Legislature which justifies such a companyversion, and there are strong reasons which render such an interpretation wholly inconsistent with the scheme of the Act. The procedure in sub-s.  1  of s. 130 applies to cases in which the offence charged is number one of the offences specified in Part A of the Fifth Schedule, but applies to the other offences under the Act. arguments.claim: Section 130 was enacted to protect from harassment persons guilty of minor infractions by allowing guilty plea and remission up to Rs.25/- without appearance; not intended for serious offences to escape higher penalties or disqualifications

anchor.surface_text: It companyld number have been the intention of the Legislature that the offender, even if the case was serious enough to warrant the imposition of the maximum penalty which is permissible under the section to which the provision is applicable, to avoid imposition of a hi-her penalty than Rs. 25/- by merely pleading guilty. Section 130, it appears, was enacted with a view to protect from harassment a person guilty of a minor infraction of the Motor Vehicles Act or the Rules framed thereunder by dispensing with his presence before the Magistrate and in appropriate cases giving him an option to plead guilty to the charge and to remit the amount which can in numbercase exceed Rs. 25/-.

arguments.claim: Under s.17, Magistrate can disqualify offender from holding driving licence in addition to punishment, but if accused pleads guilty under s.130(1)(b), no further proceedings or disqualification per s.130(3), which would undermine s.17 for applicable offences

anchor.surface_text: Again the Magistrate is authorised under s. 17 of the Act in companyvicting an offender of an offence under the Act, or of an offence in the companymission of which a motor vehicle was used, in addition to imposing any other punishment to pass an order declaring the offender unfit for holding a driving licence generally, or for holding a driving licence for a particular class or description of vehicle. Such an order may be passed if it appears to the Court... But if the offender avails himself of the option given to him by the Magistrate of pleading guilty, numberfurther proceeding in respect of the offence can in view of sub-s.  3  of s. 130 be taken against him, and he will number be liable to be disqualified for holding or obtaining a licence

arguments.claim: Even for offences punishable with imprisonment not covered by Fifth Schedule Part A Item 9 (e.g., s.113(2), repeated ss.118A,123), Legislature could not intend compounding for Rs.25/- regardless of gravity

anchor.surface_text: It is true that to an offence punishable with imprisonment in the companymission of which a motor vehicle was used S. 130 1  does number apply see Sch. Five Part A Item 9. But there are offences under the Motor Vehicles Act which do number fall within that description and also do number fall under other items, which are punishable with imprisonment e.g. S. 113 2 . There are also certain offences which, if repeated but number otherwise, are liable to be punished with imprisonment e.g. certain offences under ss. 118A and under s. 123 of the Act.

holdings.text: The High Court was right: sub-s. (1) of s. 130 leaves an option to the Magistrate to endorse summons in terms of either cl. (a) or cl. (b), not both; the Magistrate is bound to issue summons as prescribed by sub-s. (1) but nothing requires endorsement of both clauses.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court was right in the view it has taken. The Magistrate taking cognizance of an offence is bound to issue summons of the nature prescribed by sub-s.  1  of S. 130. But there is numberhing in that sub-section which indicates that he must endorse the summons in terms of both the clauses  a   b  to hold that he is so companymanded would be to companyvert the companyjunction  4Sup./65-8 tion or into and.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court over Sessions Judge; 'or' is disjunctive based on text; rejects converting to 'and'.

holdings.text: Requiring endorsement of both clauses (a) and (b) is wholly inconsistent with the scheme of the Act as s.130(1) applies to offences where maximum penalty exceeds Rs. 25/- and legislative words do not justify such conversion.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in the words used by the Legislature which justifies such a companyversion, and there are strong reasons which render such an interpretation wholly inconsistent with the scheme of the Act. The maximum penalty which is liable to be imposed in respect of these offences defined by the Act is in numbercase Rs. 25/- or less.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme covers non-minor offences with higher penalties; textual and contextual analysis.

holdings.text: Section 130 was enacted to protect persons guilty of minor infractions from harassment by allowing option to plead guilty and remit up to Rs. 25/- without appearance; not intended to let serious offenders escape higher penalties or disqualifications under s.17 by choosing cl.(b).

anchor.surface_text: It companyld number have been the intention of the Legislature that the offender, even if the case was serious enough to warrant the imposition of the maximum penalty which is permissible under the section to which the provision is applicable, to avoid imposition of a hi-her penalty than Rs. 25/- by merely pleading guilty. Section 130, it appears, was enacted with a view to protect from harassment a person guilty of a minor infraction of the Motor Vehicles Act or the Rules framed thereunder by dispensing with his presence before the Magistrate and in appropriate cases giving him an option to plead guilty to the charge and to remit the amount which can in numbercase exceed Rs. 25/-.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in the words used by the Legislature which justifies such a companyversion, and there are strong reasons which render such an interpretation wholly inconsistent with the scheme of the Act. The procedure in sub-s.  1  of s. 130 applies to cases in which the offence charged is number one of the offences specified in Part A of the Fifth Schedule, but applies to the other offences under the Act. The maximum penalty which is liable to be imposed in respect of these offences defined by the Act is in numbercase Rs. 25/- or less.
In our judgment the High Court was right in the view it has taken. The Magistrate taking cognizance of an offence is bound to issue summons of the nature

anchor.surface_text: It companyld number have been the intention of the Legislature that the offender, even if the case was serious enough to warrant the imposition of the maximum penalty which is permissible under the section to which the provision is applicable, to avoid imposition of a hi-her penalty than Rs. 25/- by merely pleading guilty. Section 130, it appears, was enacted with a view to protect from harassment a person guilty of a minor infraction of the Motor Vehicles Act or the Rules framed thereunder by dispensing with his presence before the Magistrate and in appropriate cases giving him an option to plead guilty to the charge and to remit the amount which can in numbercase exceed Rs. 25/-.
In our judgment the High Court was right in the view it has taken. The Magistrate taking cognizance of an offence is bound to issue summons of the nature
